authors: Rosenblau, G., Korn, C. W., & Pelphrey, K. A.
title: A computational account of optimizing social predictions reveals that adolescents are conservative learners in social contexts.
learning task: Rating target preferences for 3 general categories of items: activity, fashion, food
optimal response: Same rating on item as target rating on item. Not clear if this is stable within subcategory
outcome: learning rates and prediction error (difference between actual target rating and participant-predicted rating)
finding: learning rate is smaller in adolsecents. Prediction error is on average lower in adults (adults perform better)

authors: Davidow, J. Y., Foerde, K., Galván, A., & Shohamy, D.
title: An Upside to Reward Sensitivity: The Hippocampus Supports Enhanced Reinforcement Learning in Adolescence.
learning task: Butterfly cue, choose one of two flowers.
feedback: correct or incorrect, with image to be tested later for recognition
optimal response: Highest probabilistically associated choice (probably about P = .80)
finding: adolescents choose optimal choice more often than adults by task end, and have lower learning rate

title: Advice taking
learning task: 4 decks, 2 good, 2 bad, one good deck recommended by “previous participant” before task start
finding: adolescents learning rate is smaller than or equal to adults (gains, losses; n.s.), while theta (temp) is higher in adults. Adult performance looks better

title: Increased striatal activity in adolescence benefits learning.
sample: Maybe 250 or so (736 scans over 3 waves)
outcome:
“ Feedback-learning performance was defined as the
percentage of feedback during the learning phase, which was
successfully used on the next trial (stay for positive feedback,
switch for negative feedback).”
finding: learning ability improves across age from 10-30
column17: easy task (just remembering correct or incorrect feedback on last stimulus) leads to high accuracy all around, but younger people are not quite as good.

authors: Galvan, A., Hare, T. A., Parra, C. E., Penn, J., Voss, H., Glover, G., & Casey, B. J.
title: Earlier development of the accumbens relative to orbitofrontal cortex might underlie risk-taking behavior in adolescents.

authors: Kamkar, N. H., Lewis, D. J., van den Bos, W., & Morton, J. B.
title: Ventral striatal activity links adversity and reward processing in children.
outcome: proportion choose A or avoid B
finding: “Adversity was positively correlated with reward-related learning, r(38) = 0.547, but not loss-related learning, r(38) = 0.189, p = 0.242”

authors: Kamkar, N. H., Lewis, D. J., van den Bos, W., & Morton, J. B.
title: Ventral striatal activity links adversity and reward processing in children.
finding: Total Adversity was positively associated with gain-pair, r(24) = 0.39, p = 0.048, but not loss-pair accuracy, r(24) = 0.25, p = 0.218

authors: McCormick, E. M., & Telzer, E. H.
title: Adaptive Adolescent Flexibility: Neurodevelopment of Decision-making and Learning in a Risky Context.

authors: Palminteri, S., Kilford, E. J., Coricelli, G., & Blakemore, S.-J.
title: The Computational Development of Reinforcement Learning during Adolescence.

finding: Actually, no evidence of reward sensitivity as measured by Nacc related to alcohol use. “right NAcc activation explained significant variance in the average amount of glasses (B = .13, t = 2.01, p = .046)”

outcome: after selecting a brain region based on sensitivity to reward magnitude, we found that activity in this region during reward correlated with self-report of engaging in behaviors for which people expected to be rewarded. Essentially asking, if you take Nacc as “liking rewards”: How much do you like rewards? And correlating it with: How much do you think you’d do things that you think will be rewarding?
finding: correlation between Nacc activity “A priori ROI” and CARE questionnaire
